Docs.summary: Represents a Workflow role that is backed by a .

remarks.format:
## Remarks
> [!NOTE] > [!INCLUDE[DeprecatedContent](~/includes/deprecatedcontent-md.md)]
For more information about roles in ASP.NET, see [Role Providers](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=96709).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string roleName) cil managed

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string roleName, string provider) cil managed

A string that defines the role provider.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The most commonly used role providers for <xref:System.Workflow.Activities.WebWorkflowRole> are classes that inherit from <xref:System.Web.Security.RoleProvider>. These classes include <xref:System.Web.Security.AuthorizationStoreRoleProvider>, <xref:System.Web.Security.SqlRoleProvider> and <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider>.

Docs.exception: contains a null reference ( in Visual Basic).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance class System.Collections.Generic.IList`1<string> GetIdentities() cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns a generic list of ASP.NET accounts associated with the .
Docs.returns: A generic list of string values that represent the ASP.NET accounts associated with the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> supports only <xref:System.Web.Security.Roles.IsUserInRole%2A> and <xref:System.Web.Security.Roles.GetRolesForUser%2A>. Furthermore, it supports these methods only for the user account that is currently the WindowsPrincipal associated with the request context, so you cannot call <xref:System.Web.Security.Roles.GetRolesForUser%2A> for any user account in the domain. When using the <xref:System.Workflow.Activities.WebWorkflowRole.GetIdentities%2A> method with the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider>, the following provider exception is thrown:
The configured Role Provider (WindowsTokenRoleProvider) relies upon Windows authentication to determine the groups that the user is allowed to be a member of. ASP.NET Role Manager cannot be used to manage Windows users and groups. Use the SQLRoleProvider if you want to support custom user/role assignment.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The most commonly used role providers for <xref:System.Workflow.Activities.WebWorkflowRole> are classes that inherit from <xref:System.Web.Security.RoleProvider>. These classes include <xref:System.Web.Security.AuthorizationStoreRoleProvider>, <xref:System.Web.Security.SqlRoleProvider> and <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider>.
